Package introtocsHW1

Class HW1

java.lang.Object
introtocsHW1.HW1
public class HW1 extends Object
This class includes a sampling of functions that every intro to CS student should know how to implement.

    • digit

      public static int digit(int num, int ind)
      Gets the digit of the desired index in a number. For example, if num = 5762, and ind = 2 then this method will return 7. If ind = 0, then this method will return 2.
      Parameters:
      num - The number from which a digit is to be taken.
      ind - The index of the desired digit.
      Returns:
      The digit in number num at index ind.

    • binaryDigit

      public static boolean binaryDigit(int num, int ind)
      Finds the requested digit of a number in binary notation.
      Parameters:
      num - The number the digit is taken from.
      ind - the index of the desired digit.
      Returns:
      the digit, true for 1, false for 0, and the given index.

    • swap

      public static char[] swap(char a, char b)
      This method swaps the values of a and b, returning an array where the first value is b and the second value is a.
      Parameters:
      a - The first value.
      b - The second value.
      Returns:
      And array of {b, a}.

    • duckWalk

      public static boolean duckWalk(int numWalks, boolean startsAtPond)
      There are two locations, the pond, and the tree. There is a duck that likes to walk from one, to the other, in either direction. At the end of each walk, the duck is at the other location, whichever one the duck did not start the walk at. If the duck goes for one walk, and starts at the pond, then the duck finishes at the the tree. If the duck goes for two walks, and starts at the tree, then the first walk takes the duck to the pond, and the second walk takes the duck back to the tree.
      Parameters:
      numWalks - The total number of walks the duck takes. This should be nonNegative.
      startsAtPond - True if the duck starts at the pond, and false if the duck starts at the tree.
      Returns:
      True if the duck finishes at the pond and false if the duck finishes at the tree.

    • binaryToDecimal

      public static int binaryToDecimal(int binary)

      Parameters:

      Returns:

    • multiplyComplexNumbers

      public static double[] multiplyComplexNumbers(double Re1, double Im1, double Re2, double Im2)
      Multiply two complex numbers (In linear algebra you learned to multiply complex numbers.) Suppose we have two complex numbers z1 = Re1 + Im1 * i and z2 = Re2 + Im2 * i Denote their multiplication by z3 = z1 * z2, where z3 = Re3 + Im3 * i
      Parameters:
      Re1 - Real part of first number
      Im1 - Imaginary part of first number
      Re2 - Real part of second number
      Im2 - Imaginary part of second number
      Returns:
      Re3, Im3, the real and imaginary parts of z3

    • numCells

      public static int numCells(int numGenerations, int initialNumberOfCells)
      In a cell colony, each cell splits in two with every generation. Each cell dies after 5 generations. This method determines how many cells there are in the colony after a given number of generations.
      Parameters:
      numGenerations - The number of generations that transpire. This should be nonnegative.
      initialNumberOfCells - The number of cells in the colony. This should be nonnegative.
      Returns:
      The number of cells in the colony after numGenerations generations.

    • ballInBox

      public static Ball ballInBox(double xLoc, double yLoc, double xVel, double yVel, int rightWall, int cieling, double diameter)
      A ball moves an increment in a box.
      Parameters:
      xLoc - The x-locations of the ball.
      yLoc - The y-location of the ball.
      xVel - The x velocity of the ball.
      yVel - The y-velocity of the ball.
      rightWall - The x value of the right wall.
      cieling - The y value of the top wall.
      diameter - The diameter of the ball.
      Returns:
      The balls new location and velocity values [xLoc, yLoc, xVel, yVel]

    • pi

      public static double pi(int gridWidth)
      Finds pi using a sampling of points against the unit circle.
      Parameters:
      gridWidth - The square root of the number of test points.
      Returns:
      An approximation of pi.

    • runTests

      public static void runTests()
      Some helpful tests that students are strongly encouraged to run before submission. Graders will apply different tests, so be sure your code is robust. You are encouraged to write your own additional testing.

    • watchBall

      public static void watchBall()
      This should let you watch the ball bounce around the box using the code you wrote. It's a great tool to test your code, and see how simple code you write, can play a greater roll in a group project.

    • main

      public static void main(String[] args)
